The story of Chaplain Fenton's troubles began before he was stationed in Iraq.
When he served at Arlington National Cemetery, he notifies families of soldiers who had been killed.
At the cemetery, he conducted four to six funerals a day.

As the death toll mounted, Chaplain Fenton did something he'd never done before.
One night, he stopped in front of a concrete memorial wall at the base.

Fenton took out a bicycle light and started reading the names on the wall.

I sit in front of that wall and I couldn't breathe and I was crying.

Why post them here in Baqubah of all places?
He didn't get an answer that night.
For the chaplain, that was the beginning of his descent.
Psychiatrist say PTSD sufferers behave in ways that are logical when someone's trying to kill you.
But then that behavior persists after the danger is gone, behavior like hyper-vigilance to threat or emotional isolation.
Colonel John Bradley is the chief psychiatrist at Walter Reed Army Medical Center.
He says care providers including medics and chaplains seem to suffer from PTSD at about the same rate as deployed soldiers, between 10 and 17 percent.
One person's trauma may not be another person's trauma.
